definitions.definition: to admit, especially formally or to the police, that you have done something wrong or illegal
definitions.sensetop: confess to (doing) somethingconfess (that)…confess to somebody (that)…confess your crime, error, etc.

examples.text: After hours of questioning, the suspect confessed.
He confessed that he had stolen the money.
She confessed to me that she had known his true identity for some time.
We persuaded her to confess her crime.

definitions.definition: to admit something that you feel ashamed or embarrassed about
definitions.sensetop: confess somethingconfess to (doing) somethingconfess (that)…+ speechconfess yourself + adj.

examples.text: She was reluctant to confess her ignorance.
**I must confess** to knowing nothing about golf.
I confess (that) I know nothing about golf.
‘I know nothing about it,’ he confessed.
I confess myself bewildered by their explanation.
I must confess that I didn't have much faith in her ideas.
He had to confess to knowing nothing about computers.

definitions.definition: to tell God or a priest about the bad things you have done so that you can say that you are sorry and be forgiven

examples.text: They had confessed their sins and done their penance.

definitions.definition: to hear somebody confess their sins (= the bad things they have done)

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French confesser, from Latin confessus, past participle of confiteri ‘acknowledge’, from con- (expressing intensive force) + fateri ‘declare, avow’.
